title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: summarytabl R package designed simplify creation summary tables different types data. provides set functions help quickly describe: Categorical variables Multiple response variables Continuous variables function clearly prefixed based type data summarizes, making easy identify apply right tool analysis. Use functions summarize binary nominal variables: cat_tbl() creates summary table categorical variable. cat_group_tbl() summarizes two categorical variables. functions ideal summarizing binary, ordinal, Likert-type variables respondents may select multiple options: select_tbl() summarizes multiple response variables. select_group_tbl() summarizes multiple response variables group pattern. interval ratio-level variables, use: mean_tbl() generates summary statistics continuous variables. mean_group_tbl() generates summary statistics continuous variables group pattern. functions work data frames tibbles, returns tibble output. document organized three sections, focusing different set functions summarizing specific type variable. begin working summarytabl, load package: Keep reading learn function works, jump section matches type variable data ’re working .
code: library(summarytabl)

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: Let’s explore use cat_tbl() cat_group_tbl() summarize categorical variables. ’ll begin summarizing single categorical variable, race, nlsy dataset. function returns tibble three columns default: race: name variable summarized count: number observations category race percent: percentage observations category race, calculated relative total can exclude certain values eliminate missing values data using ignore na.rm arguments, respectively. Suppose want create contingency table summarize two categorical variables. can using cat_group_tbl() function. example, summarize race bthwht. applying cat_group_tbl(), ’ll recode values bthwht, changing 0 regular_birthweight 1 low_birthweight. function returns tibble four columns default: race: name row_var variable bthwht: name col_var variable count: number observations combination race bthwht categories. percent: percentage observations combination race bthwht categories, calculated relative total pivot output wider format, set pivot = "wider". display percentages, set = "percent". can also control percentages calculated displayed using margins argument. Sometimes, may want exclude specific values analysis. , use named vector list specify values exclude row_var col_var variables. example, case , Non-Black/Non-Hispanic category excluded race variable (.e., row_var) ensure NAs returned final table, na.rm.row_var set TRUE. need exclude one value row_var col_var, use named list. example , Non-Black/Non-Hispanic Hispanic categories excluded race variable.
code: cat_tbl(data = nlsy, var = "race") ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                    868   0.292 ## 2 Hispanic                 631   0.212 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.496 cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Hispanic",         na.rm = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                    868   0.370 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.630 nlsy_cross_tab <-    nlsy |>   dplyr::select(c(race, bthwht)) |>   dplyr::mutate(bthwht = ifelse(bthwht == 0, "regular_bithweight", "low_birthweight"))   cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy_cross_tab,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht") ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   race                   bthwht             count percent ##   <chr>                  <chr>              <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                  low_birthweight      102  0.0343 ## 2 Black                  regular_bithweight   766  0.257  ## 3 Hispanic               low_birthweight       42  0.0141 ## 4 Hispanic               regular_bithweight   589  0.198  ## 5 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic low_birthweight       83  0.0279 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic regular_bithweight  1394  0.468 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy_cross_tab,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 3 × 5 ##   race      count_bthwht_low_bir…¹ count_bthwht_regular…² percent_bthwht_low_b…³ ##   <chr>                      <int>                  <int>                  <dbl> ## 1 Black                        102                    766                 0.0343 ## 2 Hispanic                      42                    589                 0.0141 ## 3 Non-Blac…                     83                   1394                 0.0279 ## # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​count_bthwht_low_birthweight, ## #   ²​count_bthwht_regular_bithweight, ³​percent_bthwht_low_birthweight ## # ℹ 1 more variable: percent_bthwht_regular_bithweight <dbl> # Default: percentages across the full table sum to one cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               pivot = "wider",               only = "percent") ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                             <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                             0.257           0.0343 ## 2 Hispanic                          0.198           0.0141 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic            0.468           0.0279 # Rowwise: percentages sum to one across columns within each row cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               margins = "rows",               pivot = "wider",               only = "percent") ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                             <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                             0.882           0.118  ## 2 Hispanic                          0.933           0.0666 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic            0.944           0.0562 # Columnwise: percentages within each column sum to one cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               margins = "columns",               pivot = "wider",               only = "percent") ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                             <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                             0.279            0.449 ## 2 Hispanic                          0.214            0.185 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic            0.507            0.366 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = c(race = "Non-Black,Non-Hispanic")) ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   race     bthwht count percent ##   <chr>     <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black         0   766  0.511  ## 2 Black         1   102  0.0680 ## 3 Hispanic      0   589  0.393  ## 4 Hispanic      1    42  0.0280 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = list(race = c("Non-Black,Non-Hispanic", "Hispanic"))) ## # A tibble: 2 × 4 ##   race  bthwht count percent ##   <chr>  <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black      0   766   0.882 ## 2 Black      1   102   0.118

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: Next, let’s explore use select_tbl() select_group_tbl() functions summarize multiple response variables. Multiple response variables commonly used survey research, psychology, health sciences represent items (questions) respondents can select one option several items measure underlying concept. Examples include symptom checklists, scales like depression index multiple items, questions allowing respondents choose applicable answers. example, depressive dataset contains eight variables share variable stem: dep, one representing different item used measure depression. Using select_tbl() function, can summarize participants’ responses items showing many respondents chose answer option (.e., value) every variable. Alternatively, can choose summarize specific variables passing names var_stem argument setting var_input argument "name". default, missing values removed using listwise deletion. switch pairwise deletion instead, set na_removal = "pairwise". display output wide format, set pivot = "wider". ’s common practice group multiple response variables another variable. type descriptive analysis allows meaningful comparisons across different segments dataset. select_group_tbl(), can create summary table multiple response variables, grouped either another variable dataset matching pattern variable names. example, often want summarize survey responses race. First, recode race variable values eight depressive index variables depressive dataset, replacing numeric categories descriptive string labels easier interpretation. Next, use select_group_tbl() function summarize responses eight variables race: select_tbl(), setting pivot argument "wider" reshapes table wide format, using "pairwise" na_removal argument ensures missing values addressed pairwise deletion. ignore argument can used exclude specific values analysis. example , value often removed eight depression index variables, Non-Black/Non-Hispanic category excluded race variable. group_type set variable (default), margins argument controls percentages calculated presented. Another way use select_group_tbl() summarize responses match specific pattern, survey waves time points. enable feature, set group_type = "pattern" provide desired pattern group argument. example, stem_social_psych dataset contains variables capture student responses sense belonging STEM community two distinct time points: “w1” “w2”. can summarize responses using pattern-based approach, time points (e.g., “w1” “w2”) serve grouping variables. Use group_name argument assign descriptive name column containing matched pattern values. can also include variable labels summary table using var_labels argument. Finally, use argument choose information return.

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: Finally, let’s look use mean_tbl() mean_group_tbl() functions summarize continuous variables. mean_tbl() function allows generate descriptive statistics either set continuous variables share common stem individual continuous variables. resulting summary table includes key metrics variable’s mean, standard deviation, minimum value, maximum value, count non-missing observations variable. sdoh dataset contains six variables describing characteristics health care facilities, begin prefix HHC_PCT. Using mean_tbl() function, can generate summary statistics variables: Alternatively, want generate summary statistics subset variables, can specify names directly var_stem argument set var_input = "name" indicate ’re referencing variable names rather shared stem. can also specify missing values removed, using na_removal argument. Consider adding variable labels using var_labels argument help make variable names easier interpret. Similar working multiple response variables, ’s common practice group continuous variables another variable enable meaningful comparisons across different segments dataset. mean_group_tbl() function facilitates type descriptive analysis generating summary statistics continuous variables, grouped either specific variable dataset matching patterns variable names. example, ’s often useful present summary statistics demographic categories region, gender, age, race. can control values exclude missing data handled using ignore na_removal arguments. specify values ignore, use named vector list, name corresponds variable stem specific variable name. Another way use mean_group_tbl() summarize responses based shared pattern, survey time points. enable feature, set group_type = "pattern" specify desired pattern group argument. Consider dataset compiled researchers examining many symptoms participants reported ’d long illness. (fictitious) dataset, responses collected three time points: “t1” (baseline), “t2” (6-month follow-), “t3” (one-year follow-). Using pattern-based approach, can group variables time points generate summary statistics phase data collection. example , first create symptoms_data dataset use mean_group_tbl() function generate summary statistics variables begin prefix symptoms contain substring matching pattern "_t\\d", underscore followed letter “t” single digit, indicating different time points. ignore argument also used exclude value -999 analysis. make output easier understand, use group_name argument add label column shows grouping values matched patterns. can also use var_labels argument display descriptive labels variable. Finally, can choose information return using argument.

title: Generate Summary Tables for Continuous, Ordinal, and Categorical Data
text: summarytabl R package provides functions tabulating summarizing continuous, ordinal, categorical variables data frames. Whether ’re exploring data preparing report, summarytabl helps quickly generate clear, structured summaries, can spend less time wrangling data time interpreting .
